titleStmt.title: A hybrid method based on krill herd and quantum-behaved particle swarm optimization

affiliation.orgName: School of Computer Science and Technology

analytic.title: A hybrid method based on krill herd and quantum-behaved particle swarm optimization

biblStruct.note: Received: 23 January 2015 / Accepted: 7 April 2015 Ó The Natural Computing Applications Forum 2015

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: A novel hybrid Krill herd (KH) and quantumbehaved particle swarm optimization (QPSO), called KH-QPSO, is presented for benchmark and engineering optimization. QPSO is intended for enhancing the ability of the local search and increasing the individual diversity in the population. KH-QPSO is capable of avoiding the premature convergence and eventually finding the function minimum; especially, KH-QPSO can make all the individuals proceed to the true global optimum without introducing additional operators to the basic KH and QPSO algorithms. To verify its performance, various experiments are carried out on an array of test problems as well as an engineering case. Based on the results, we can easily infer that the hybrid KH-QPSO is more efficient than other optimization methods for solving standard test problems and engineering optimization problems.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: With the development of real-life engineering techniques, the related optimization problems are becoming more and more complex. Experience had clearly pointed out the inefficiency of the traditional methods to solve such complicated problems. In order to cope with this limitation, a variety of modern nature-inspired intelligent algorithms has been put forward and applied to solve optimization problems. Some of them, such as particle swarm optimization (PSO) [1][2][3][4], ant colony optimization (ACO) [5][6][7], bat algorithm (BA) [8][9][10][11][12], differential evolution (DE) [13][14][15], firefly algorithm (FA) [16][17][18], biogeographybased optimization (BBO) [19][20][21][22][23], cuckoo search (CS) [24][25][26][27][28], artificial bee colony (ABC) [29][30][31], ant lion optimizer (ALO) [32], multi-verse optimizer (MVO) [33], charged system search (CSS) [34][35][36], gravitational search algorithm (GSA) [37][38][39], animal migration optimization (AMO) [40], interior search algorithm (ISA) [41], grey wolf optimizer (GWO) [42,43], harmony search (HS) [44][45][46], krill herd (KH) [47], genetic algorithm (GA) [48] and stud GA (SGA) [49], have solved several challenging problems that are hard to address by the traditional optimization techniques.

Swarm intelligence-based optimization techniques are one type of extensively used intelligent algorithms. They are well capable of finding the optimal solutions through all the individuals simultaneously instead of each individual. KH method [47], as one of these swarm intelligence techniques, was studied by several researchers because it has a relatively simple but effective framework for function optimization. KH was proposed by Gandomi and Alavi [47] through the idealization of communicating and foraging behaviors of krill swarms.

On the other hand, since quantum computation (QC) theory was proposed, it has significantly boosted the development of computational science. QC has shown tremendous computing power in the last two decades. A Qbit has two statuses that are ON and OFF; especially, the status of Q-bit is unknown until it is read out. Thus, if we have L Q-bits to operate, there is a feasible vast space of 2 L values that can be used for computation. This advantage indicates that a number of complex problems can be solved simultaneously with the help of this feature. The basic operation on Q-bits is a rotation.

Due to the parallel computation of the QC theory, it has been used extensively in various applications. In this context, one of the most famous applications is the introduction of the QC theory into the optimization methods. Up to now, the QC theory has been successfully combined with several metaheuristic optimization methods. Some major efforts in this area include hybridizing the QC theory with membrane algorithm [50], multi-objective evolutionary algorithm [51], ABC [52] and PSO [53]. Among these hybrid methods, QPSO is one of the most famous ones [53]. QPSO has been developed to overcome the main limitation of the PSO in converging to the best solution every time [54]. All particles in QPSO show a quantum behavior instead of the classical Newtonian dynamics shown in original PSO [55]. Due to its excellent performance, QPSO has been used in many applications, such as streamflow forecasting and three-dimensional route planning.

KH has the strong ability of global search and is easy to merge into other optimization strategy [56]. In order to enable the KH algorithm to find the best solution more efficiently for a certain set of problems, a new hybrid strategy combined with the QPSO method, called KH-QPSO, is proposed in this work. In KH-QPSO, the whole population is divided into two equal subpopulations. KH and QPSO implement their own operators simultaneously in order to update the individuals on their subpopulations, respectively. After that, two subpopulations are combined into one whole population. This combination can fully use the information of the best individual for this generation and is used to preserve the randomness of the solution and avoid premature convergence. Likewise, it is used to update individuals for the next generation.

The organization of the paper is as follows. The next two sections introduce the process of the KH and QPSO, respectively. Section 4 represents the hybrid KH-QPSO model. Subsequently, in Sect. 5, an array of experiments on various benchmarks and an engineering case are conducted. The final section provides our conclusion and points out our future work orientation.

div.head: KH algorithm
div.p: KH [47] is a novel kind of optimization strategy capable of solving complex problems. KH is also a member of swarm intelligence algorithms family that takes advantage of the evolving behaviors of krill individuals. It is based on the idealization of the krill swarms when hunting for food and communicating with each other. The KH method repeats the implementation of the three movements and takes search directions that proceed to the best solution. The position of a krill is idealized into three actions as [47]:
1. movement influenced by other krill; 2. foraging action; 3. physical diffusion. KH adopted the following Lagrangian model as Eq. (1).
div.formula: dX i dt ¼ N i þ F i þ D ið1Þ
div.p: where N i is the motion induced by other krill, F i is the foraging motion, and D i is the physical diffusion. In Eq. ( 1), i = 1, 2,…, NP, and NP is population size. For the first motion, its motion direction, a i , is primarily decided by a target effect, a local effect and a repulsive effect. For krill i, it can be given as:
div.formula: N new i ¼ N max a i þ x n N old ið2Þ
div.p: where N max is the maximum induced speed, x n is the inertia weight, and N i old is the last motion. The second motion is mainly decided by the two factors: the food location and its previous experience. For the ith krill, it can be defined as:
div.formula: F i ¼ V f b i þ x f F old i ð3Þ b i ¼ b food i þ b best ið4Þ
div.p: where V f is the foraging speed, x f is the inertia weight for the second motion, and F i old is the last motion. The third motion is essentially a random process. It contains two parts: a maximum diffusion speed and a random directional vector. It can be expressed as follows:
where D max is the maximum diffusion speed and d is the random vector.

div.head: Neural Comput & Applic
div.p: Based on the three above-mentioned movements, the position of a krill from t to t ? Dt is given as:
div.formula: X i t þ Dt ð Þ¼X i ðtÞ þ Dt dX i dtð6Þ
div.p: In standard KH, the process of movement influenced by other krill, foraging action and physical diffusion continue for a fixed number of generations or until a termination condition is satisfied. More detailed description about KH algorithm can be referred as [47].

Since the KH is an effective method, many other scholars have done many researches about it. Li et al. [57] analyzed a deficiency of KH which cannot achieve the excellent balance between exploration and exploitation in optimization process and proposed an improved krill herd (KH) with linear decreasing step (KHLD). Wang et al. hybridized some other state-of-the-art metaheuristic as mutation operation with KH, such as HS [56], DE [58], BBO [59] and GA [60]. These hybridized heuristics can make better balance between exploration and exploitation. Instead of random distribution as used in the basic KH method, Le ´vy flight is introduced into KH in [61,62]. In addition, chaos theory is used to adjust the parameters [63,64], and these optimized parameters can make KH method implement better.

div.head: The QPSO algorithm
div.p: Inspired by the swarm behavior of some species, PSO [1] is a kind of the classic optimization strategy. PSO implements a population-based search to optimize a function. All possible solutions, called particles, consist of the population and they are randomly initialized. According to the optimal experience of its own and the whole population, the velocity and position are updated by Eqs. ( 7) and (8), respectively.
div.formula: V tþ1 i ¼ V t i þ ar 1 ðX Ã i À X t i Þ þ brðg Ã À X t i Þ ð 7Þ X tþ1 i ¼ X t i þ V tþ1 i Dtð8Þ
div.p: where X i and V i are the position and velocity of particle i, respectively, g * and X i * are the optimal position of particle i and the whole particles, respectively, w is an inertia parameter that can control the dynamics of flight, and a and b are often called the learning parameters [65]. In Eq. ( 8), time interval Dt is equal unit. Many new improvements and applications of PSO have been proposed in [66][67][68].

One of the disadvantages of the basic PSO algorithm is that it cannot converge to the optimal solution every time [54]. QPSO is a hybrid metaheuristic method based on the PSO and QC theory [53]. All the individuals in QPSO show a quantum feature instead of the classical Newtonian dynamics in PSO [55]. The representation of the state of the particles in QPSO is given by the wave function instead of the position and velocity used in PSO [55].
Through trajectory analysis [69], it has proven that PSO may find the final best solution if each particle can find its local best solution, p i = (p i1 , p i2 ,…, p iD ) described as follows:
div.formula: p i ðkÞ ¼ uP i ðkÞ þ ð1 À uÞP g ðkÞ ð9Þ
div.p: where u is a random number in (0, 1). Here p i is a stochastic attractor of particle i that are related to P i and P g . It can be seen that the velocity is no use in QPSO. The position in QPSO is a single property for an individual particle, which is updated as [53]:
div.formula: X i ðk þ 1Þ ¼ p i ðkÞ AE ajCðkÞ À X i ðkÞjln 1 uð10Þ
div.p: where a is the contraction-expansion coefficient and u is a random number in (0, 1). Mean best position C(k) can be computed by the mean value of P i :
div.formula: C k ð Þ ¼ C 1 k ð Þ; C 2 k ð Þ; Á Á Á ; C D k ð Þ ð Þ ¼ 1 M X M i¼1 P i1 ðkÞ; 1 M X M i¼1 P i2 ðkÞ; Á Á Á ; 1 M X M i¼1 P iD ðkÞ !ð11Þ
div.p: The update of QPSO given by Eq. ( 10) permits particles to move in the whole search space every time, while PSO only lets the particles appear in a limited space. The QPSO algorithm is a global convergent method but the PSO not [54]. In addition, velocity is no use in QPSO, so QPSO is much simpler than PSO. It has experimentally shown that QPSO has better performance than PSO [55].

div.head: KH-QPSO
div.p: When the krill is attracted to the local best solution, it has no ability of jumping out of local minimum in the standard KH method. In order to overcome these disadvantages, the KH method is hybridized with QPSO algorithm to form a novel hybrid KH-QPSO method. In general, a hybrid metaheuristic method attempts to combine more than two metaheuristic methods. This can fully exert the useful features from the original algorithms. In the proposed hybrid KH-QPSO, the idea of QPSO is introduced into the KH in order to improve its search ability.
First of all, an initial population (krill and particles, or for simplicity ''individual'') is randomly generated.
The whole population can be divided into two equal subpopulations at random.
After initialization, for the first half population (subpopulation one), it is subjected to implement the above three motions for all the krill as shown in Sect. 2.
Simultaneously, for the remaining half population (subpopulation two), it is subjected to implement the search processes of the particles as shown in Sect. 3.

After updating the solutions in the population, the two subpopulations are composed of one population. Furthermore, we can sort the population according to their fitness and the best individual is selected at this iteration. Subsequently, this optimization procedure is repeated.

In the KH-QPSO process, the update of the population is obtained by the partition as well as the combination of the population. In the partition process, a random selection operation is carried out in order to divide the whole population into two equal subpopulations. This operation is intended to primarily increase the diversity of the population as well as to jump out of premature convergence and stagnation problems. After all individuals complete the searching process, we combine the two subpopulations, obtained by KH and QPSO, into one population. In this way, all individuals can share the position information with each other in the search space. The aim of this operation is to enable the individuals to find the best solution with less time and maintain the instructive information.

Furthermore, for the search strategy used in the KH-QPSO method, on the one hand, for the krill, the position of the krill is updated according to the principle of the KH. On the other hand, for the particles, a modification is made on the particle position in terms of the rules in the QPSO method.

The principal idea behind the KH-QPSO is based on four considerations. Firstly, hybrid methods attempt to utilize the merits of two different original methods. Secondly, the best individuals are shared by combining two subpopulations into one population. This combination can also exchange useful features from krill and particles, and this prevents the individuals from not converging prematurely. Thirdly, no additional operator is added to the basic KH and QPSO algorithms to develop KH-QPSO. Fourthly, for most engineering problems, the fitness evaluation is computationally expensive. In KH-QPSO, we use the fixed population size, and this significantly increases the probability of finding the optimal solution without introducing additional computational cost. That is one of the significant reasons why QPSO is hybridized with KH.
The detailed description of the KH-QPSO for solving optimization problems can be given below:
Step 1: Initialization An initial population including NP individuals is produced at randomly. Other parameters used in KH and QPSO are also set.
Step 2: Evaluation All the individuals in the population are evaluated according to its position.
Step 3: Partition The whole population are equally divided into two subpopulations (subpopulation one and subpopulation one) at random. This partition is prepared for the next KH and QPSO process.

Step 4: KH process For the NP/2 individuals in the subpopulation one, their position is updated by the three motions in KH method as described in Sect. 2. The main step of KH process can be described as follows:
for i=1:NP/2 (all krill in subpopulation one) do Implement three motions.
Update the position according to the above motions.

div.head: end for i
div.p: Step 5: QPSO process Corresponding to subpopulation one, for the NP/2 individuals in the subpopulation two, the position of individual is updated by the rules in QPSO method as described in Sect. 2. The main step of QPSO process can be described as follows:
div.formula: Update P i (k) and P g (k)
div.p: Calculate the mean best C(k) by Eq. ( 11) Calculate p(k) by Eq. ( 9)
Update the position X i (k+1) by Eq. ( 10)
end for i for i=1:NP/2 (all particles in subpopulation two) do
Step 6: Combination After a population (subpopulation one and subpopulation two) of all the individuals are generated in this way, the two subpopulations are combined into one population.
Step 7: Finding the best solution Compute the fitness for all the individuals and find the best solution for this generation.
Step 8: Stop or not If the best solution is the required solution, the KH-QPSO stops, else return to Step 2.
The description of the KH-QPSO can also be given in Fig. 1.

div.head: Simulation results
div.p: In this section, the KH-QPSO method is evaluated from different aspects by using various experiments conducted in benchmark functions (see Table 1) and an engineering optimization problem. In order to obtain fair results, all the implementations are conducted under the same conditions as shown in [64]. More detailed descriptions of all the benchmarks can be referred as [70]. Note that the dimensions of functions F01-F13, F14-F16, F17-F23, F24-F26, F27-F28 and F29-F53 are 2, 3, 4, 6, 10 and 20, respectively. For six difficult test functions F54-F59, their dimensions are 2, 2, 2, 2, 4 and 4, respectively. More detailed descriptions of benchmarks F54-F59 can be referred as [71].

div.head: Comparisons of KH-QPSO with other methods
div.p: The performance of KH-QPSO was compared with nine optimization methods (ABC [29], ACO [5], BBO [19], DE [13], GA [48], HS [44], KH [47], QPSO [53] and SGA [49]) on fifty-three optimization problems. It is worth

div.head: Is termination condition met?
div.p: Update P i (k) and P g (k)
Compute the mean best C(k) by Eq. ( 11)
Compute p(k) by Eq. ( 9)

Update the position X i (k+1) by Eq. ( 10 mentioning that Gandomi and Alavi [47] have shown that the KH II has the best performance by comparing with four types of KHs. Therefore, the KH II is selected as the standard KH algorithm.
The same parameters for KH, KH-QPSO and QPSO are set as follows: V f = 0.02, D max = 0.005 and N max = 0.01. For the parameters used in the other methods, their settings are the same as [19,59].

For each method, population size NP and maximum generation Maxgen are set to 50. It is well known that all the intelligent methods are based on certain stochastic distribution, so 200 independent runs are carried out for each method on each test problem in order to get representative performances. The obtained function values are recorded in Tables 2, 3 and 4. The optimal solution for each test problem is highlighted. For all the tables, the total number of functions in which the optimization method has the best performance is provided in the last row. Note that the scales that are used to normalize values in the tables are fully different with each other; therefore, values from different tables are not comparative. The detailed normalization process can be defined as follows.
Firstly, the real function values are presented by matrix
div.formula: A m9n = [A 1 , A 2 ,…, A i ,…, A m ] T . A i means the ith row, and a ij is an item in A, 1 B i B m, 1 B j B n.
div.p: Here, m = 38 and n = 6 denote the number of benchmark functions and algorithms used in this paper, respectively.
Secondly, the minimum of the ith row b i is calculated according to the Eq. ( 12).
div.formula: b i ¼ minðA i Þ ð12Þ
div.p: Thirdly, the normalized results C m9n can be obtained as shown in Eq. (13).
div.formula: c ij ¼ a ij b ið13Þ
div.p: The values in the following tables are c ij that are normalized by the above method. As an example, if matrix A is defined as
After normalized, the matrix C is defined as

From Table 2, it can be seen that, on average, KH-QPSO has the best performance on thirty-nine out of fiftynine benchmarks. QPSO, ABC and DE have the second best performance on twenty-six, twenty and twenty functions out of fifty-nine functions, respectively. For other methods, KH and BBO are inferior to the above methods. For the best solutions, Table 3 shows that KH-QPSO is well capable of finding the optimal solutions on forty-five out of fifty-nine benchmarks. QPSO and KH can search for the best solutions on twenty-nine and twenty-eight out of fifty-nine benchmarks. Generally, ABC, DE and SGA have the similar performance with each other. So the other methods do. Furthermore, Table 4 indicates that the standard deviation (Std) of KH-QPSO is smaller than other ten methods on twenty out of fifty-nine benchmarks. QPSO has the smallest Std on sixteen out of fifty-nine benchmarks. In other words, for most benchmarks, KH-QPSO is able to find the optimal solutions within smaller range than other methods. And it is therefore more practical and feasible than others. From Tables 2, 3 and 4, all the methods have the similar performance on low-dimensional benchmarks, while for high-dimensional benchmarks, KH-QPSO is the best method at searching for the optimal function values. This is because the low-dimensional functions are too simple to differentiate the ten methods.

For the computational requirements, they are collected as shown in Table 2. From Table 2, ACO and BBO use the same and least time among ten methods. For KH-QPSO, its consuming time is between KH and QPSO. How to accelerate KH-QPSO is still further study.

Furthermore, to intuitively show the superiority of the KH-QPSO, evolution curves of KH, KH-QPSO and QPSO on some most typical benchmarks are provided in this section (see Figs. 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 and 7). In order to highlight the optimization process, the population size ( 20) is selected here.
From Fig. 2, it can be seen that the function value obtained by KH-QPSO is significantly better than KH and QPSO. In addition, the QPSO is the worst method among three methods for F35.

Figure 3 shows the results for the F37 benchmark. It can be observed from this figure that the function value obtained by KH-QPSO is significantly better than KH and QPSO. In addition, the KH is the worst method among three methods for F33.
For the F38 benchmark, Fig. 4 indicates that KH-QPSO outperforms QPSO and KH all the time, as similarly observed for F35.
For the F39 benchmark, though the function values obtained by KH and KH-QPSO are almost equal sometimes, KH-QPSO is better than KH. In this case, KH and KH-QPSO have a better performance than QPSO.
For the F41 case, Fig. 6 reveals that KH, KH-QPSO and QPSO start the optimization process from the same point. However, KH-QPSO has the best performance among them.
For the F42 case, Fig. 7 indicates that KH-QPSO and KH have a similar final performance, and they both outperform QPSO.
From the Tables 2, 3, 4 and Figs. 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, it can be concluded that our proposed hybrid metaheuristic KH- QPSO algorithm is well capable of finding the best function minimum.

div.head: Comparisons using t test
div.p: Based on the final search results of 200 independent trials on every function, Table 5 presents the t values on every function of the two-tailed test with the 5 % level of significance between the KH-QPSO and other optimization methods. In the table, the value of t with 398 degrees of freedom is significant at a = 0.05 by a two-tailed test.

Boldface signifies superior performance of KH-QPSO with respect to the compared algorithm. For the last three rows, the ''Better,'' ''Equal'' and ''Worse'' represent that KH-QPSO is better than, equal to, and worse than certain comparative method on certain benchmark. Here, we take the comparison between the KH-QPSO and the KH for instance. The former significantly outperformed the latter on thirty functions, does as better as the latter on twentythree functions and is worse than the latter on six functions.

To conclude, we may safely opine that the KH-QPSO generally performs better than KH on the solution accuracy. Furthermore, for QPSO, the number of ''Better,'' ''Equal'' and ''Worse'' are 9, 45 and 5, respectively. These three numbers indicate that KH-QPSO has the similar performance with QPSO on most functions. That is, KH-QPSO can never be worse than QPSO for most cases.
Although the KH-QPSO performed slightly poorer on some functions, Table 5 reveals that it outperforms the other nine methods for most functions.

div.head: The study of the number of fitness evaluations
div.p: Here, we look at the number of fitness evaluations on fourteen high-dimensional functions for each method to certain fixed function values. In our experiments, the fixed function values are set to opt ? 2. opt indicates the optimum for every function. The maximum of fitness evaluations is set to 50,000. That is to say, if a method cannot converge to the values opt ? 2 within the maximum of fitness evaluations (50,000), it will stop, too, and return the 50,000. All the results are recorded in the Table 6. It clearly demonstrates that, for the five functions F29, F34, F44, F49 and F50, KH-QPSO find the satisfactory results with the least fitness evaluations. BBO, KH and SGA have the similar performance with each other, and they can converge to the fixed values with the least fitness evaluations on the three functions (F42, F43, F47), (F33, F46, F48) and (F38, F39, F45), respectively. To summarize, KH-QPSO can find the satisfactory solution by using the least fitness evaluations.

div.head: Sensor selection problem
div.p: Except the standard functions discussed in the section above, one more engineering optimization problem is also used to validate the effectiveness of the KH-QPSO method.
The sensor selection problem can be considered as a test problem to validate the KH-QPSO method. The detailed sensor selection problem can be found in [19].

Here, ten optimization methods are used to search for a sub-optimal sensor set. The results on the sensor selection problem are recorded in Table 7. It can be seen that KH-QPSO produces superior performance than other nine methods in terms of average, best and worst performance. Furthermore, the Std of KH-QPSO is much smaller than other methods. That is, KH-QPSO has a relatively high possibility of finding the satisfactory sensor set. The future research in this area may be revolved around the following. Firstly, the influence of the KH-QPSO parameters on convergence and performance can be carefully analyzed and investigated in order to make KH-QPSO implement in the best way. Secondly, the good performance of the proposed hybrid KH-QPSO method suggests the reasonability of combining KH with other search strategies. Fourthly, more benchmarks and engineering optimization problems might be used to test the proposed method, such as feature selection [72], capacitated vehicle routing, multimodal K-shortest viable path, and water, geotechnical and transport engineering. KH-QPSO would also be compared with more widely used methods, such as CMA-ES and RCGAs. Finally, instead of simply merging the two sets of populations at each generation in our present work, in our future research work, we intend to undertake more in-depth study about how to make full use of two populations to create a better solution based on them.
